bibl.title: Letter from Joseph A. LePrince, February 27, 1915

div1.p: LePrince discusses his survey of Hartsville, South Carolina, and gives his recommendations to inhibit mosquito breeding.

div1.head: Letter from Joseph A. LePrince, February 27, 1915
div1.opener:
(copy)
Hartsville (1
Feb 27/15
Inspection at Hartsville -S.C - Feb 27/15
J A LePrince
div1.p:
The long ditch recently constructed parallel & close to the Railway track
will eliminate a large former mosquito production area - (See sketch)
In case mosquito larvae occur in it an oil drip should be installed near
its source, at a point where the water moves freely-. Should water collect
& be held back by the surcharged ditch banks (as shown in diagram Z)
such openings as are necessary should be made.

The small pond in the poultry yard across the highway road from the
school house (B C D R) may be completely drained by a contour ditch (A B C D) at
to of hill-. The wooden grating across ditch to prevent escape of fouls should
be replaced by poultry netting (see sketch “Y”) & width of ditch increased slightly
near fence. The bottom of the ditch should be so graded as to dry area
(B C D R). Stagnant water (T T) should be drained to large ditch nearby. All
of above work can be accomplished by a few men in a half day-.
Adjacent to the long ditch is (wet land S.S.) If it produces mosquitoes
it should be drained to long ditch, by ditch of sufficient depth. It may
be that a small seepage intercepting ditch is advisable there. A few
small pools & wet places remain between the long ditch & the Railway track
which can be eliminated by inexpensive ditching. The work so far
accomplished is very good-. Another limited production area that
needs attention is (Pool K - See Sketch) Two adult culex larvae were
taken there on Feb 27/15- The mill pond was well supplied with tap-
Hartsville (2
Feb 27/15
feeding numerous and no mosquito larvae were found in it-

The club house and the cow stable (both close to the shore of the pond)
were examined for hibernating anopheles but proved negative.
The washhouse, stable & pig pen where Deriveau, Taylor & LePrince
found many Anopheles last Summer were examined. Two
Anopheles were present in the pig pen but escaped before I
could get closer than two feet from them-.
